Do not change this unless you know the ports on the remote machine have been altered.

data.name: ConnectControlViewEditHelp
data.value:
Change the connection properties of the selected Warewolf Server.

Allows you to change remote server URL, Port and Authentication.

localhost cannot be edited in this way.

data.name: ConnectControlViewToggleConnectionHelp
data.value:
Disconnects or Connects to the selected remote Warewolf Server.

Connected Servers will be Disconnected and vice versa.

localhost cannot be disconnected and should always be connected. If it is not connected, try restarting the Warewolf Server service in Task Manager.

} /* selected link */ a:active { text-decoration: underline; color: rgb(243,112,13); } label { display: inline-block; cursor: pointer; position: relative; padding-left: 25px; margin-right: 15px; font-size: 13px; data.name: WebServiceRequestHeadersTableHelp
data.value:
Web Service Request Headers.

You can use variables here in the value field like [[Header_ResponseType]]. These variable values will be requested when you drop the service on the workflow designer.

data.name: AssignHelpVariable
data.value:
Only variables go in here. To assign a value to a variable, put the variable here. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.
Allowed:
Data
  1. [[Scalar]]
  2. [[Recordset(n).Field]]
  3. [[Recordset(*).Field]]
  4. [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: AssignHelpNewValue
data.value:
Any variable and/or data goes in here. To assign a value to a variable, put the value in here. If you put an = as the first character, it will turn into a calculation e.g. =[[qty]]*[[price]]
Allowed:
Data
  1. [[Scalar]]
  2. [[Recordset(n).Field]]
  3. [[Recordset(*).Field]]
  4. [[Recordset().Field]]
= fx

data.name: BaseConversionHelpBaseInput
data.value:
Any variable and data goes in here. To convert Text, Hex, Binary and Base64, put the data to be converted in here.
Allowed:

data.name: CalculateForAggregatesHelpFx
data.value:
Any variable and/or data goes in here. To perform a calculation, put the calculation in here in BODMAS format. To use the aggregate functions, use the recordset (*) notation e.g. SUM([[Staff(*).Salaries]]) will perform one calculation and give one result that is the total of all the Salaries fields in the Staff() recordset. Aggregate functions are:
sum() average() product() count()
max() median() min() var()
stdev() concatenate() choose() irr()
counta() subtotal() avedev() and()
or() isnull() istext() npv()

data.value: Comments do not execute and are place holders for future services or tools or simply to leave commentary inside the workflow. Allowed: Notes and comments will not be executed at run time but will show up in the debug output.

data.name: CreateJSONHelpInput
data.value:
To create JSON data, enter the Name and Data of the JSON variables. To create JSON Arrays use a single recordset field with a star for every record e.g. [[rec(*).name]] To create JSON Objects, use a comma separated list of recordset fields, or, just the recordset name to use the whole recordset. e.g. [[rec(*).surname]], [[rec(*).name]], [[rec(*).middle]] or simply [[rec(*)]]
Allowed:

  2. [[Recordset(n).Field]]
  3. [[Recordset(*).Field]]
  4. [[Recordset().Field]]

Allowed:

  2. [[Recordset(n).Field]]
  3. [[Recordset(*).Field]]
  4. [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: ForEachHelpForEachType
data.value: Generally Replaces the * in the activity with the relevant index. e.g. If 1-3 is provided then [[Customer(*).ID]] will execute as [[Customer(1).ID]], [[Customer(2).ID]], [[Customer(3).ID]]. * in Range allows you to input a range of indexes. * in CSV allows a specific set of indexes to be specified e.g. 1,5,7,9. * in Recordset will execute every index in the given recordset. * in Executes will execute the activity a given number of times and replace the * with the number of times it has executed e.g. 1,2,3... up to the number you specify. No Subs. Execution WILL NOT substitute * with anything. The inner item(s) will execute given number of times in full. Allowed: na

A single Recordset will yield the best performance. Do not mix, scalars and/or different recordsets for optimum performance. data.name: SqlBulkInsertHelpTimeout
data.value:

If you specify 30, then 30 seconds will be allowed for the entire operation to complete before timing out. data.name: SettingsSecurityResourceHelpContribute
data.value: By Default this group will be able to Edit or Delete this resource. To do this they can also View and Execute.

data.name: SettingsSecurityResourceHelpExecute
data.value: By Default this group will be able to call or execute this workflow.

data.name: SettingsSecurityResourceHelpResource
data.value: To set specific permissions for a resource on this server, select the resource here. Any permissions applied to this resource will OVERWRITE the server settings above. By specifying a resource here, it will not inherit permissions from the server (above).

data.name: SettingsSecurityResourceHelpView
data.value: By Default this group will be able to open and view this resource. Typically this is used by Business Analysts to sign off work and participate in the development process.

data.name: SettingsSecurityResourceHelpWindowsGroup
data.value: To set resource specific permissions, enter the Windows Group name or "Public" here followed by the system access for that group. Permissions are cumulative in nature e.g. If someone is a member of two groups and only one of those groups has Contribute permission, then that member WILL have Contribute permission. Public is an internal Warewolf group that applies to everyone.

data.name: SettingsSecurityServerHelpAdministrator
data.value: Administrators can amend security permissions and change server settings. The local machine Administrators are automatically given this permission. Giving Public access to this permission is akin to turning security off and is not recommended.

data.name: SettingsSecurityServerHelpContribute
data.value: By Default this group will be able to add new resources, edit resources and delete existing resources on this server. To do this they can also View and Execute.

data.name: SettingsSecurityServerHelpDeployFrom
data.value: By Default this group will be able to deploy resources off this server.

data.name: SettingsSecurityServerHelpDeployTo
data.value: By Default this group will be able to deploy resources onto this server. Deploy may mean overwriting existing work and can be done without Contribute privileges.

data.name: SettingsSecurityServerHelpExecute
data.value: By Default this group will be able to call or execute resources on this server.

data.name: SettingsSecurityServerHelpView
data.value: By Default this group will be able to open and view resources on the server. Typically this is used by Business Analysts to sign off work and participate in the development process.

data.name: SettingsSecurityServerHelpWindowsGroup
data.value: To set server wide permissions for security, enter the Windows Group name or "Public" here followed by the system access for that group. You can click on the ellipsis for help with identifying the correct windows group. By Default these permissions will permeate all resources on the server, unless specified below in Resource Permissions. Permissions are cumulative in nature e.g. If someone is a member of two groups and only one of those groups has Contribute permission, then that member WILL have Contribute permission. The Public group grants any and every user those permissions.

data.name: SettingsSecurityServerBrowseHelpWindowsGroup
data.value: Opens the windows group picker for this computer. If this server is on another domain, you will need to either manually type the Group name in, or launch a studio from a PC that is on that domain to get access to the group picker. Warewolf has a built in group for and called Public.

data.name: SettingsPerfCounterRemoveResourceHelpText
data.value: Removes the performance counters for this specific resource

data.name: SettingsSecurityResourceBrowseHelpResources
data.value: Resource picker

data.name: SettingsSecurityResourceBrowseHelpWindowsGroup
data.value: Resource picker

data.name: QuickVariableAppendHelpText
data.value: Append will add the variables onto the list of variables already in the input grid. The values of the last row will be repeated for all of these additional values.

data.name: QuickVariablePrefixWithHelpText
data.value: To append something onto the front of the variables in your list, type it in here. For recordsets, type recordsetname(). Don't forget the "." after the "()" You do not need to put the "[[" in.

data.name: QuickVariableSplitAndAtHelpText
data.value: Select the criteria to split the variables in the list. This will be the pattern used to repeat against the Variable List box. Char will split on the characters you specify, like comma or | </. Index will split on the numeric index from the previous split. New Line will split on carriage return. Space will split on blank space. Tab splits on a tab character.

data.name: QuickVariableSuffixWithHelpText
data.value: To append something onto the end of the variables in your list, type it in here. You do not need to put the "]]" in.

data.name: QuickVariableVariableListHelpText
data.value: Type or paste all the variables you want to use in here. You can paste in any format. If you are adding variables into a grid with a drop down or other input, the values from the last row will be repeated, so set them before adding these variables.

data.name: QuickVariableReplaceHelpText
data.value: Replace will replace the current list of variables with this list. The values of the first row will be repeated for all of these new values.

data.name: PreviewInputHelpText
data.value: Preview (recordset field) This is a variable from an input field. Use comma-separated values for each index e.g. [[Trip(*).Distance]] = 45, 32, 12, 5 Preview (scalar field - including indexed recordsets and ()) This is a variable from an input field. Put some test info in and click the Preview button to test your result.

data.name: BaseConversionHelpFromType
data.value: Select the type of data you are converting from. e.g. If the data is Binary and you would like Text, then select Binary here. Allowed: na

data.name: BaseConversionHelpToType
data.value: Select the type of data you are converting to. e.g. If the data is Binary and you would like Text, then select Text here. Allowed: na

data.name: SftpPrivateKeyValue

data.name: DropBoxDownloadFileName

data.name: DropboxResultHelpText
data.value: The result of the drop box operation will be assigned to this value

data.name: DropBoxDeleteFileNameHelpText
data.value: Specify the Dropbox file or folder you would like to delete. This is the path from the root of the Dropbox account.

data.name: DropBoxFileListFileName
data.value: Returns the contents of the Dropbox folder you specify here. This is the folder structure you want to list on Dropbox. You can specify the type of information returned by selecting either Files (returns only files), Folders (Returns only folders) or Files and Folders for everything.

data.name: DropboxReadFiles
data.value: Returns the files that are in the given folder, or all the files in the folder and all the files in the sub folders if Recursive is selected.

data.name: DropboxReadFolders
data.value: Returns the folders that are in the given Dropbox folder, or all the folders in the folder and all the folders in the sub folders if Recursive is selected.

data.name: DropboxReadFilesFolders
data.value: Returns a list of everything in the Dropbox folder provided or everything including sub folders if Recursive is selected.

data.name: DropBoxFileListRecursive
data.value: When selected, will recursively look up everything from the given path onwards - to a maximum of 2000 items. NOTE: Dropbox has a max return count of 2000.

data.name: CalculateHelpFx
data.value:
Any variable and/or data goes in here. To perform a calculation, put the calculation in here in BODMAS format. Using (*) notation for recordsets, will perform the calculation and give a result, for each record. To use aggregate functions on the whole recordset e.g. to Sum all the [[Product(*).Price]] fields in a recordset, use the Aggregate Calculate tool.

Allowed:
Data
  1. [[Scalar]]
  2. [[Recordset(n).Field]]
  3. [[Recordset(*).Field]]
  4. [[Recordset().Field]]
absReturns the absolute value of a number. The absolute value of a number is the number without its sign.
acosReturns the arccosine, or inverse cosine, of a number. The arccosine is the angle whose cosine is specified number. The returned angle is given in radians in the range zero to pi. To convert the result from radians to degrees, multiply by 180/PI().
acoshReturns the inverse hyperbolic cosine of the given number. The inverse hyperbolic cosine is the angle whose hyperbolic cosine is specified number.
andReturns true if all values are true or returns false if one or more values are false.
asinReturns the arcsine, or inverse sine, of a number. The arcsine is the angle whose sine is the specified number. The returned angle is given in radians in the range -pi/2 to pi/2. To express the arcsine in degrees, multiply the result by 180/PI().
asinhReturns the inverse hyperbolic sine of the given number. The inverse hyperbolic sine is the angle whose hyperbolic sine is specified number.
atanReturns the arctangent, or inverse tangent, of a number. The arctangent is the angle whose tangent is the specified number. The returned angle is given in radians in the range -pi/2 to pi/2. To express the arctangent in degrees, multiply the result by 180/PI().
atan2Returns the arctangent, or inverse tangent, of the specified x and y-coordinates. The arctangent is the angle from the x-axis to a line containing the origin (0, 0) and a point with coordinates (x_num, y_num). The angle is given in radians between -pi and pi, excluding -pi.
atanhReturns the inverse hyperbolic tangent of the given number. The inverse hyperbolic tangent is the angle whose hyperbolic tangent is specified number.
avedevReturns the average deviation from the average of all numeric values.
averageReturns the average (arithmetic mean) of one or more values.
bin2decReturns the decimal value of a text representation of a number in the binary number system.
bin2hexConverts a text expression representing a binary number to a text expression representing the same number in the hexadecimal number system.
bin2octConverts a text expression representing a binary number to a text expression representing the same number in the octal number system.
ceilingReturns the smallest multiple of the significance (defaults to 1) greater than or equal to the specified number.
charReturns the character specified by the code number from the character set for your computer.
chooseReturns one of the values provided in its arguments based on the number in the first argument.
codeReturns a numeric code for the first character in a text expression using the character set used by your computer.
combinReturns the number of possible combinations given a set of items and a number of chosen items from that set.
complexReturns a complex number represented as a text expression in the format "x + yi" or "x + yj" by combining a real and imaginary number.
concatenateJoins all the arguments into one text expression.
convertConverts a value from one system of measurement to another, such as meters to inches or hours to seconds.
cosReturns the cosine of the given angle.
coshReturns the hyperbolic cosine of a number.
countCounts the number of references that contain numbers.
countaCounts the number of references that are not blank.
dateReturns the sequential serial number that represents a particular date.
dateaddReturns a date to which the specified interval has been added.
datediffReturns a value indicating the number of intervals between two DateTime values.
datevalueReturns the date value of the specified date text.
dayReturns the day of month of a date value.
days360Returns the number of days between two dates based on a 360-day year.
dbReturns the depreciation of an asset for a specified period using the fixed-declining balance method.
dbnullReturns something that represents a non-existent value.
ddbReturns the depreciation of an asset for a specified period using the double-declining balance method or some other method specified.
dec2binReturns a text expression representing the specified decimal value as a binary number.
dec2hexReturns a text expression representing the specified decimal value as a hexadecimal number.
dec2octReturns a text expression representing the specified decimal value as an octal number.
degreesConverts radians to degrees.
deltaCompares two numbers and returns one if they are equal or zero if they are not.
dollardeConverts a dollar amount expressed as a fraction into a dollar amount expressed as a decimal.
dollarfrConverts a dollar amount expressed as a decimal into a dollar amount expressed as a fraction.
edateReturns a date that is the specified number of months before or after the start date.
eomonthReturns a date that is at the end of the month which is the specified number of months before or after the start date.
errortypeReturns a number corresponding to an error value.
evenRounds a positive number up and a negative number down to nearest even integer.
expReturns e raised to the power of the specified number. The constant e equals 2.71828182845904.
factReturns the factorial of a number.
factdoubleReturns the double factorial of a number.
findReturns the starting position of one text expression within another, case sensitively.
fixedRounds a number to the specified number of decimals and returns the result as text with or without commas.
floorReturns the largest multiple of the significance (defaults to 1) less than or equal to the given number.
fvReturns the future value of an investment based on periodic.
gcdReturns the greatest common divisor of one or more integer values.
gestepCompares two numbers and returns one if the first number is greater than or equal to the second or returns zero if not.
hex2binConverts a text expression representing a hexadecimal number to a text expression representing the same number in the binary number system.
hex2decReturns the decimal value of a text representation of a number in the hexadecimal number system.
hex2octConverts a text expression representing a hexadecimal number to a text expression representing the same number in the octal number system.
hourReturns the hour of a time value.
ifReturns one value if the specified condition evaluates to true and another value if it evaluates to false.
iferrorReturns one of two values depending on whether or not the first value is an error or not.
imabsReturns the absolute value of a complex number.
imaginaryReturns the imaginary coefficient of a complex number.
imargumentReturns the argument theta, an angle expressed in radians.
imconjugateReturns the conjugate of a complex number.
imcosReturns the cosine of a complex number.
imdivReturns the quotient of two complex numbers (Dividend / Divisor).
imexpReturns the exponential of a complex number.
imlnReturns the natural logarithm of a complex number.
imlog10Returns the base-10 logarithm of a complex number.
imlog2Returns the base-2 logarithm of a complex number.
impowerReturns the complex number raised to the specified power.
improductReturns the product of one or more complex numbers.
imrealReturns the real coefficient of a complex number.
imsinReturns the sine of a complex number.
imsqrtReturns the square root of a complex number.
imsubReturns the difference between two complex numbers.
imsumReturns the sum of one or more complex numbers.
infoReturns information about the current operating environment.
intRounds a number down to the nearest integer.
intrateReturns the interest rate for a fully invested security.
ipmtReturns the interest payment for a given period for an investment, based on periodic, constant payments and a constant interest rate.
irrReturns the internal rate of return for a series of cash flows.
isblankReturns true if the value is blank.
isdbnullReturns true if the value represents a non-existent value.
iserrReturns true if the value is any error value except #N/A.
iserrorReturns true if the value is any error value.
isevenReturns true if the value is an even number, else returns false.
islogicalReturns true if the value is a logical value (true or false).
isnaReturns true if the value is the #N/A (value not available) error value.
isnontextReturns true if the value is any item that is not text.
isnullReturns true if the value is non-existent.
isnumberReturns true if the value is a number.
isoddReturns true if the value is an odd number, else returns false.
isrefReturns true if the value is a reference.
istextReturns true if the value is a text value.
lcmReturns the least common multiple of one or more integer values.
leftReturns the first character or characters in a text expression.
lenReturns the number of characters in a text expression.
lnReturns the natural logarithm of a number.
logReturns the logarithm of a number to the base specified.
log10Returns the base-10 logarithm of a number.
lowerConverts all uppercase letters in a text expression to lowercase.
maxReturns the largest number in a set of numbers.
medianReturns the median of a set of numbers. The median is the middle number when the numbers are sorted or the average of the two middle numbers if there are an even number of specified numbers.
midReturns a specific number of characters from a text expression.
minReturns the smallest number in a set of numbers.
minuteReturns the minute of a time value.
modReturns the remainder after a number is divided by a divisor. The result has the same sign as the divisor.
monthReturns the month of a date value.
mroundRounds a number to the nearest multiple of another number.
multinomialReturns the multinomial of a set of numbers. The multinomial is the ratio of the factorial of a sum of values to the product of their factorials.
nConverts a value to a number.
naReturns the #N/A (value not available) error value.
networkdaysReturns the total number of whole work days between the specified dates, excluding any specified holidays.
notReverses a logical value (changes true to false and false to true).
nowReturns a value representing the current date and time.
nperReturns the number of periods for an investment based on periodic, constant payments and a constant interest rate.
npvCalculates the net present value of an investment by using a discount rate and a series of future payments (negative values) and income (positive value).
nullReturns a non-existent value.
oct2binConverts a text expression representing an octal number to a text expression representing the same number in the binary number system.
oct2decReturns the decimal value of a text representation of a number in the octal number system.
oct2hexConverts a text expression representing an octal number to a text expression representing the same number in the hexadecimal number system.
oddRounds a positive number up and a negative number down to the nearest odd integer.
orReturns true if one or more values are true; returns false if all values are false.
piReturns the constant pi, which is 3.14159265358979.
pmtCalculates the payment for a loan based on constant payments and a constant interest rate.
powerReturns the result of a number raised to a power.
ppmtReturns the payment on the principal for a given period for an investment based on periodic, constant payments and a constant interest rate.
productMultiplies all the numbers given as arguments and returns the product.
pvReturns the present value of an investment.
quotientReturns the integer portion of a division. This will discard the remainder of the division.
radiansConverts degrees to radians.
randReturns an evenly distributed random number greater than or equal to 0 and less than 1
randbetweenGenerates a pseudorandom integer between two specified numbers.
rateReturns the interest rate per period of an annuity.
replaceReplaces part of a text expression.
reptRepeats text a specific number of times.
rightReturns the last character or characters in a text expression.
romanConverts a number into a roman number as a text expression.
roundRounds a number to a specified number of digits.
rounddownRounds a number to down to the specified number of digits.
roundupRounds a number to up to the specified number of digits.
searchReturns the 1-based index of one string within another, searching case insensitively.
searchbReturns the 1-based index of one string within another, searching case insensitively.
secondReturns the second of a time value.
seriessumReturns the sum of a power series.
signReturns the sign of a number (-1, 0, or 1).
sinReturns the sine of the specified angle.
sinhReturns the hyperbolic sine of a number.
slnReturns the straight-line depreciation of an asset for one period.
sqrtReturns a positive square root of a number.
sqrtpiMultiplies the specified number by pi and returns the square root of the result.
stdevReturns the standard deviation of a population sample.
subtotalCalculates the subtotal in one of more references.
sumSums all the numbers given as arguments and returns the sum.
sydReturns the sum-of-years' digits depreciation of an asset for a specified period.
tanReturns the tangent of the specified angle.
tanhReturns the hyperbolic tangent of the specified angle.
textConverts the value to text based on the specified format.
timeReturns a number that represents a particular time value.
timevalueConverts a text expression representing a time to its equivalent time value.
todayReturns the current date.
trimRemoves all spaces from text except for single spaces between words.
truncTruncates a number to an integer by removing the fractional part of the number.
typeReturns a number representing the type of value: number = 1; text = 2; logical value (true or false) = 4; error value = 16; array = 64.
upperConverts all lowercase letters in a text expression to uppercase.
valueConverts a text expression that represents a number to a number.
varReturns the variance of a population sample.
weekdayReturns a number representing the day of the week of the specified date.
weeknumReturns the number of the week into which the specified date falls.
workdayReturns a work day the specified number of days from the specified date, excluding any specified holidays.
yearReturns the year of a date value.
FALSEReturns the logical value false.
TRUEReturns the logical value true.

data.name: AssignObjectHelpVariable
data.value:
Only objects go in here. To assign a value to an object, put the object path in here.
Allowed:
[[@Object.Property]]
[[@Object.Object(n).Property]]

data.name: AssignObjectToolTipVariable
data.value: Only objects go in here. To assign a value to an object, put the object path in here.

data.name: AssignObjectHelpNewValue
data.value:
Any object and/or data goes in here. To assign a value to a object, put the value in here. If you put an = as the first character, it will turn into a calculation e.g. =[[qty]]*[[price]]
Allowed:
  1. [[Scalar]]
  2. [[Recordset(*).Field]]
  3. [[Recordset().Field]]
  4. [[@Object(*).Field]]
  5. [[@Object().Field]]
  6. [[@Object.InnerCollection().Field]]

data.name: SelectAndApplyDataSourceHelpText
data.value:
Only collections go in here.
You can use the (*) or () notation for record sets or object arrays.
This is the collection of items that will be iterated over.

For example to iterate over all ages in the person recordset this field will contain [[person(*).age]].
Allowed:
  1. [[Recordset(*).Field]]
  2. [[Recordset().Field]]
  3. [[@Object(*).Field]]
  4. [[@Object().Field]]
  5. [[@Object.InnerCollection().Field]]

data.name: SelectAndApplyAliasHelpText
data.value:
Specify an alias for the selected data.
This needs to conform to variable notation.
This will be the value that will be acted upon in the activity inserted below.
To ensure that the original values are updated ensure that the result of the activity is set to this value.
Allowed:
  1. [[alias]]

data.name: EditRabbitMQSourceHelp
data.value: Edit RabbitMQ Source

data.name: NewRabbitMQSourceHelp
data.value: New RabbitMQ Source

data.name: RabbitMQSourceHelp
data.value: Select a preconfigured RabbitMQ source or add a new one.

data.name: RabbitMQHelpQueueName
data.value:
Provide a name of the Queue you want to consume from. The Queue should already be in the RabbitMQ Source in your server. Note: The Queue name is case sensitive.

Allowed:
Data
  1. [[Scalar]]
  2. [[Recordset(n).Field]]
  3. [[Recordset(*).Field]]
  4. [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: RabbitMQHelpResponse
data.value:
Only variables go in here. This will be the response of what you have Consumed from your Queue

Allowed:
  1. [[Scalar]]
  2. [[Recordset(n).Field]]
  3. [[Recordset(*).Field]]
  4. [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: RabbitMQHelpPrefetch
data.value:
Provide number of messages that can be consumed concurrently. This will pre-fetch the given number of messages and block further traffic until you Acknoledge something. This ensures that a maximum of the given number of unAcknowldged messages are pre-fetched at one time.

Allowed:
Data
  1. Interger Value
  2. [[Scalar]]

data.name: RabbitMQHelpTimeOut
data.value:
The Queue might be empty when the Consumer makes the initial attempt to Consume the message. Put the number of seconds you want the consumer to delay when attempting to consume messages from the queue. After the specified time (in seconds) has elapsed, the consumer will retire.

Allowed:
Data
  1. Interger Value
  2. [[Scalar]]

data.name: RabbitMQHelpIsDurable
data.value: When RabbitMQ source quits or crashes it will forget the queues. Durable will prevent queues getting lost after the source is up again.

data.name: RabbitMQHelpAcknowledge
data.value: Aknowledge will send back result from the consumer to tell RabbitMQ that a particular message has been received, processed and that RabbitMQ is free to delete it.

data.name: RabbitMQHelpRequeue
data.value: Marking this as True will leave the message you consumed in the queue. Leaving it UnChecked will remove it from the Queue after it has bee consumed.

data.name: RabbitMQHelpIsExclusive
data.value: Exclusive queues may only be accessed by the current connection, and are deleted when that connection closes. Passive declaration of an exclusive queue by other connections are not allowed.

data.name: RabbitMQHelpIsAutoDelete
data.value: If set, the queue is deleted when all consumers have finished using it. The last consumer can be cancelled either explicitly or because its channel is closed. If there was no consumer ever on the queue, it won't be deleted. Applications can explicitly delete auto-delete queues using the Delete method as normal.

data.name: RabbitMQHelpMessage
data.value:
This is the actual content you want to add in the Queue When the Consumer consumes the message, this content will be returned as the response.

Allowed:
Data
  1. [[Scalar]]
  2. [[Recordset(n).Field]]
  3. [[Recordset(*).Field]]
  4. [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: RabbitMQHelpResult
data.value:
Returns Success or Failure depending on the success of the message publish.

Allowed:
  1. [[Scalar]]
  2. [[Recordset(n).Field]]
  3. [[Recordset(*).Field]]
  4. [[Recordset().Field]]

data.name: XpathToolTipResults
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the result of the Xpath expression. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record. Each Xpath expression returned will be added to the result recordset in a new record or comma separated list if a scalar variable is defined.

data.name: ZipToolTipUsername
data.value: For protected resources, specify the Username of an account with permission to access the destination. By default the account running Warewolf Server.exe service will be used.

data.name: ZipToolTipResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns Success or will be blank depending on the success of the Zip action. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: ZipToolTipPassword
data.value: For protected resources, specify the Password of an account with permission to access the source. By default the account running Warewolf Server.exe service will be used.

data.name: ZipToolTipForceoverwrite
data.value: If a file already exists, you can force a new one to overwrite the old one.

data.name: ZipToolTipFileFolder
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To zip a file or folder, put the full path of what you want zipped in here. You can use File System, URI, SFTP, FTP or FTPS format.

data.name: ZipToolTipDestination
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. Put the full path of the destination you are zipping to here. You can use File System, URI, SFTP, FTP or FTPS format.

data.name: ZipToolTipCompressiontype
data.value: The system will try and match your zipping requirements as far as possible. None creates the new file with the content and adds no compression - fastest. Partial attempts some compression. Normal will apply standard compression. Max will compress the zipped file as much as possible - slowest.

data.name: ZipToolTipArchivePassword
data.value: Specify the password needed to open the zip file here. Leaving the Archive Password blank will result in no password being required to open the file.

data.name: XPathToolTipXPath
data.value: Xpath notation describing the route to the data in the XML input.

data.name: XPathToolTipXML
data.value: Any data or variable can go in here. To traverse an XML document and return information from it, enter the raw XML in here.

data.name: WriteFileToolTipUsername
data.value: For protected resources, specify the Username of an account with permission to perform this action. By default the account running Warewolf Server.exe service will be used.

data.name: WriteFileToolTipResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns Success or will be blank depending on the success of the Write action. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: WriteFileToolTipPassword
data.value: For protected resources, specify the Password of an account with permission to perform this action. By default the account running Warewolf Server.exe service will be used.

data.name: WriteFileToolTipFilename
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To write content to a file, put the full path and file name in here. You can use File System, URI, SFTP, FTP or FTPS format.

data.name: WriteFileToolTipContents
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. Put the contents you want written to the file in here.

data.name: WorkflowDesignerSecurityToolTipNone
data.value: You are not authorized to edit this resource

data.name: WindowsAuthenticationToolTip
data.value: Connect using the logged on users credentials

data.name: WebRequestToolTipURL
data.value: Any data or variable can go in here. To traverse and retrieve the raw response from a webpage, enter it in here.

data.name: WebRequestToolTipTimeOut
data.value: The length of time to wait for a web request to complete before failing

data.name: WebRequestToolTipResult
data.value: Only a single variable goes in here. Returns the response text of the web get request.

data.name: WebRequestToolTipHeader
data.value: To supply additional header information in your get request, put the header info in here.

data.name: WebInsertToolTipColumn
data.value: Test data for the execution

data.name: ViewJsonObjectTooltip
data.value: Click to see the JSON representation of this object.

data.name: UserNameToolTip
data.value: Enter the user name you want to connect with

data.name: UserAuthenticationToolTip
data.value: Connect using a specific account

data.name: UnzipToolTipZipname
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To unzip a file, put the full path and zip file name in here. You can use File System, URI, SFTP, FTP or FTPS format.

data.name: UnzipToolTipUsername
data.value: For protected resources, specify the Username of an account with permission to access the source. By default the account running Warewolf Server.exe service will be used.

data.name: UnzipToolTipResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns Success or will be blank depending on the success of the Unzip action. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: UnzipToolTipPassword
data.value: For protected resources, specify the Password of an account with permission to access the source. By default the account running Warewolf Server.exe service will be used.

data.name: UnzipToolTipForceoverwrite
data.value: If a file or folder already exists, you can force a new one to overwrite the old one.

data.name: UnzipToolTipDestination
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. Put the full path of the destination you are unzipping to here. You can use File System, URI, SFTP, FTP or FTPS format.

data.name: UnzipToolTipArchivePassword
data.value: Specify the password needed to open the zip file here. Leaving the Archive Password blank will result in no archive password being used to open the file.

data.name: UniqueToolTipReturnFields
data.value: Which fields from the recordset would you like returned when a Unique combination is found? Use a comma separated list of the fields. Where multiple rows are the same, the first one will be deemed Unique.

data.name: UniqueToolTipResults
data.value: Returns the unique combinations into the variables specified. If there are multiple fields being returned, there should be multiple Results fields specified. Use a comma to separate the variables.

data.name: UniqueToolTipInFields
data.value: To identify unique information in a recordset, put the comma separated fields that need to be unique in here.

data.name: ToolboxSearchToolTip
data.value: Search filter for your tools

data.name: ToolboxClearSearchTooltip
data.value: Clear the filter box

data.name: SystemInformationToolTipSysInfoType
data.value: Select the type of system information you would like to use.

data.name: SystemInformationToolTipResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the type of system information selected.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipUseInternalTransaction
data.value: When specified, each batch of the bulk-copy operation will occur within a transaction.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipTimeout
data.value: The number of seconds you would like the operation to complete in. All batches in total must complete within this time period. The default is 0 which will be no time constraint. If you specify 30, then 30 seconds will be allowed for the entire operation to complete before timing out. Note, the timeout is purely for the actual SQL connection and not the preparation of the data to be inserted.

data.name: SQLBulkInsertToolTipTable
data.value: Select a table to perform the bulk insert into. If the table schema has changed or recently added to the source, click the refresh button.

data.name: SQLBulkInsertToolTipSkipblankrows
data.value: Blank records will not be added to the SQL table.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns Success or the record numbers with errors. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipKeepTableLock
data.value: Obtain a bulk update lock for the duration of the bulk copy operation. When not specified, row locks are used.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipKeepIdentity
data.value: Preserve source identity values. When not specified, identity values are assigned by the destination.

data.name: SQLBulkInsertToolTipInputData
data.value: To bulk insert data into a table, put the data to insert in here. Using recordset (*) notation will put the entire recordset in and is the normal usage scenario for large data inserts to SQL. A single Recordset will yield the best performance. Do not mix, scalars and/or different recordsets for optimum performance. To quickly change the input data, press the Quick Variable Input button and amend the mappings as necessary.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipInputColumn
data.value: To bulk insert data into a table, put the data to insert in here. Using recordset (*) notation will put the entire recordset in and is the normal usage scenario for large data inserts to SQL. A single Recordset will yield the best performance. Do not mix, scalars and/or different recordsets for optimum performance. To quickly change the input data, press the Quick Variable Input button and amend the mappings as necessary.

data.name: SqlBulkInsertToolTipFireTriggers

data.name: FormatNumberToolTipRoundvalue
data.value: At what point in the number should the rounding be done as a factor of 10? e.g. 3 will round to 3 decimal places and negative 3 (-3) will round to the nearest thousand.

data.name: FormatNumberToolTipRoundType
data.value: How would you like to round the number? None: No rounding is done Normal: 5,6,7,8,9 round up & 1,2,3,4 round down Up: 1-9 all round up Down: 1-9 all round down

data.name: FormatNumberToolTipResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the formatted number. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: FormatNumberToolTipNumber
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To format a number, put the number in here.

data.name: FormatNumberToolTipDecimalsToShow
data.value: How many decimals should be returned as a factor of 10? e.g. 3 will show 0.000 and negative 3 (-3) will show 15000 as 15.

data.name: ForEachToolTipForEachType
data.value: Generally Replaces the * in the activity with the relevant index. e.g. If 1-3 is provided then [[Customer(*).ID]] will execute as [[Customer(1).ID]], [[Customer(2).ID]], [[Customer(3).ID]]. * in Range allows you to input a range of indexes. * in CSV allows a specific set of indexes to be specified e.g. 1,5,7,9. * in Recordset will execute every index in the given recordset. * in Executes will execute the activity a given number of times and replace the * with the number of times it has executed e.g. 1,2,3... up to the number you specify. No Subs. Execution WILL NOT substitute * with anything. The inner item(s) will execute given number of times in full.

data.name: FindToolTipTo

data.name: FindToolTipResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the indexes of the successful matches. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record. If there are multiple results and a scalar is used, then each result will be separated with a comma.

data.name: FindToolTipRequireAllMatchesToBeTrue

data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. Put the index of the string you are looking for in here.

data.name: DateTimeToolTipTimeType
data.value: Select the unit of time to add or subtract. This is ignored if the unit is blank or 0.

data.name: DateTimeToolTipResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the formatted and/or added/subtracted date time. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: DateTimeToolTipOutputformat
data.value: Describe the format you would like the date time to be returned in. Leaving this field blank will assume the same as the Input Format. To include text or non-date information use 'around the text you want to escape'. e.g. Time is now 15 hours and 33 minutes. Would have an output format of 'Time is now' 24hr 'hours and' min 'minutes.'

data.name: DateTimeToolTipInputformat
data.value: Describe the format of the date time you are entering. e.g. 23-July 1978 would be described as dd-MM yyyy. Leaving this field blank will assume the system date time format. To escape text or non-date information use 'around the text you want to escape'. e.g. Time is now 15 hours and 33 minutes. Would have an input format of 'Time is now' 24hr 'hours and' min 'minutes.'

data.name: DateTimeToolTipDatetime
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To format a date time, or to add/subtract from a date time, put it in here. Leaving this field blank will give you the system date time.

data.name: DateTimeToolTipAddtime
data.value: Put a positive or negative number here to add or subtract from the input date time. Leave this field blank if you do not want to change the date time.

data.name: DateTimeDifferenceToolTipResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the difference in time between the two date times. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: DateTimeDifferenceToolTipOutputType
data.value: Select the unit of time to output the difference in.

data.name: DateTimeDifferenceToolTipInputFormat
data.value: The format of the eg. yyyy-dd-mm

data.name: DateTimeDifferenceToolTipDatetime2
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To find the difference in time between two date times, put the second date time in here. The format needs to be the same for the two. Leaving this field blank will give you the system date time.

data.name: DateTimeDifferenceToolTipDatetime1
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To find the difference in time between two date times, put the first date time in here. The format needs to be the same for the two. Leaving this field blank will give you the system date time.

data.name: DataSplitToolTipWithtype
data.value: Select where you would like to split the data.

data.name: DataSplitToolTipUsing
data.value: For Index use the number of characters that this split will use. For Char put any characters or combination of characters you would like. Not applicable to New Line, Tab or End

data.name: DataSplitToolTipString
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To split a value into one or more variables, put the value in here. You can process entire file content or just trim the white space from a variable.

data.name: DataSplitToolTipSkipBlankRows
data.value: For file processing you can skip rows in the file that are blank. This saves you having to remove them afterwards.

data.name: DataSplitToolTipResults
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the split data in the pattern as described by the results. The variable pattern will be repeated until the end of the input data. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: DataSplitToolTipProcessDirection
data.value: Default direction to process is forward or left to right (reading direction). Selecting Backwards will process from the end of the data (right) to the beginning (left).

data.name: DataSplitToolTipInclude
data.value: If you would like the data or item you are splitting on to be included in the result data, select this checkbox.

data.name: DataSplitToolTipEscape
data.value: If there is an occurrence or an item being split on, that should not be split on, it will be preceded with this character. e.g., a comma separated file might have a comma in a name, so don’t split on it if it is preceded by / or some other characters.

data.name: DataMergeToolTipWithtype
data.value: Select the type of merge you would like between each piece of merged data, if any.

data.name: DataMergeToolTipUsing
data.value: For Index use the number of characters that this merge will use. It will either trim if too little, or pad if too much. For Char put any characters or combination of characters you would like. Not applicable to New Line or Tab

data.name: DataMergeToolTipResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the merged string. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: DataMergeToolTipPadding
data.value: If Index is being used and there is extra space between the data supplied and the number of index characters, you can specify what makes up the padding e.g. 0 for numbers or blank space for text.

data.name: DataMergeToolTipInput
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To join two or more pieces of data together list them in the order you would like them joined. If you use recordset (*) notation, the list will be repeated for every record.

data.name: DataMergeToolTipAlignType
data.value: For Index you can specify if your data is aligned to the right or left. E.g. Text is normally left and numbers normally right.

data.name: DataListVariableInputTooltip
data.value: The variable name you want to declare, without the [[ ]] braces

data.name: DataListOutputCheckBoxTooltip
data.value: Will return this variable as a response

data.name: DataListInputCheckBoxTooltip
data.value: Allows this variable to be passed into the service

data.name: CreateToolTipResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns Success or will be blank depending on the success of the Create action. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: CreateToolTipPassword
data.value: For protected resources, specify the Password of an account with permission to perform this action. By default the account running Warewolf Server.exe service will be used.

data.name: CreateToolTipForceOverWrite

data.name: CreateToolTipFileFolder
data.value: Any variable and/or data goes in here. To create a file or folder, put the full path and file or folder name here. You can use File System, URI, SFTP, FTP or FTPS format.

data.name: CreateJSONToolTipResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns the inputs in JSON format. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset () will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: CreateJSONToolTipName
data.value: The JSON variable name will default to the Warewolf variable name in the Data column. Array and Object names will default to the recordset name used. Object data names will be the field names of the recordset.

data.name: CreateJSONToolTipInput
data.value: To create JSON data, enter the Name and Data of the JSON variables. To create JSON Arrays use a single recordset field with a star for every record e.g.[[rec(*).name]] To create JSON Objects, use a comma separated list of recordset fields, or, just the recordset name to use the whole recordset. e.g. [[rec(*).surname]], [[rec(*).name]], [[rec(*).middle]] or simply [[rec(*)]]

data.name: CountToolTipResult
data.value: Only variables go in here. Returns a number specifying how many records/indexes are in the recordset. You can use [[Scalar]] as well as [[Recordset().Fields]]. Using recordset() will add a new record and (*) will assign every record.

data.name: CountToolTipRecordset
